text: BBC breakfast is a national British
morning television news program
simolcast on BBC 1 in the BBC news
channel. It is presented live from Media
City UK and contains a mixture of news,
sport, weather, business and feature
items. The program is broadcast 7 days a
week, every week of the year, including
weekends and public holidays. Adam
Bullmore is the editor. He had been the
deputy editor for 5 years. Allison Ford,
previously the UK editor for BBC News
Gathering, was the editor of the program
until her death in July
2013. Her appointment followed the
departure of David Kerode to 5 News.
History Breakfast Time was the first BBC
breakfast program with Ron Neil as
producer. It was conceived in response
to the plans of the commercial
television company TVM to introduce a
breakfast television show. Breakfast
Times first broadcast was on January
17th, 1983, featuring multiple
presenters, Frank Bao, Selena Scott,
Nick Ross, and Russell Grant. The
atmosphere of the set was intended to
encourage a relaxed
informality. A set that mimicked a
living room rather than a studio with
red leather sofas and B and Ross wearing
jumpers and open neck shirts. This
allowed for an unconventional mix of
authoritative and high brown news and
informative and entertainment features
that made the show dominate the new
genre and trance the anticipated threat
by the star name commercial TV rival. So
a senior government minister might be
subjected to intense questioning while
sitting on the red sofa to be then
included in the presentation of a food
cooking demonstration.
Breakfast time lasted 150 minutes
initially being transmitted between 6.30
m and 9 arm euro moving to a
650m to 9.20m slot on February 18th
1985. A bomb detonated at 254 a.m. on
October 12th in the Grand Hotel Brighton
with a purpose to kill Prime Minister
Margaret Thatcher and her cabinet who
was staying at the hotel for the
Conservative Party conference. Nick Ross
presented Breakfast Time on his own as
live coverage came in from Brighton. Ron
Neil departed from the program and on
November 10th, 1986, a more conventional
news focus was introduced featuring a
news desk, presenters in Smart Dress and
a time reduced program broadcast that
began at 7:00 a.m. and ended any time
between 8.30 30 and
8.55m. Presenters included Kirsty Walk,
John Stapleton, Jeremy Paxman, and Sally
Magnon. On October 2nd, 1989, the
program was renamed Breakfast News,
followed a more authoritative tone with
a set modeled on the conventional desk
style found with main news bulletins and
started at
6.30m. A considerable portion of the
first half hour was devoted to business
news. In January 1993, the business news
coverage extended to an hour-ong program
in its own right, beginning at 6:00 a.m.
Breakfast News started at 700 a.m. Next
came the merging of the separate
programs of BBC 1 and BBC News 24 into
one single simolcast starting from
October 2nd, 2000. Since April 2006, the
BBC News Channel has screened rolling
news coverage from 8.30, 30 while
breakfast continues on BBC 1 until 9.15
a.m. In April 2008, BBC News 24 was
renamed BBC News as part of aa
550,000 rebranding of the BBC's news
output complete with a new studio and
presentation. On May 2nd, 2006,
Breakfast moved into Studio N6 at
Television Center with other BBC 1 news
programs that required a larger set
design that included walls of Barco
video screens. The original screen
scenes of Sirrus clouds on a blue sky
were changed as a result of viewer
comments that it looked too cold. A
euro. Their replacement was with orange
squares of the same design as those
appearing in the program's new title
sequence, which were designed to hide
any joins or faults between the screens
which had previously been obvious. The
screens eventually displayed visuals
needed for story content, different
backgrounds, graphics, and still
photographs. More importantly, the set
had a generic visual style that could be
used for other programs such as the
national news bulletins without much
additional physical change. The program
celebrated its 20th anniversary on
January 17th, 2003. On January 28th,
2008, Breakfast returned to the TC7
studios where Breakfast Time had been
based following its move from the BBC
Lime Grove Studios. On March 2nd, 2009,
Breakfast relaunched with a new set in
studio background. The backdrop
resembles that of the BBC News Channel
as do the new Breakfast titles. In July
2010, the BBC announced that Breakfast
was moving to their new studios in
Sulford Keys. The BBC announced that
with the April 2012 move to Sulford,
co-presenter Shan Williams and sports
presenter Chris Holland preferred not be
included in the move to the north of
England. Williams left Breakfast on
March 15th, 2012, but she continues
doing other assignments with the BBC. On
December 12th, 2011, the first of
several presenter changes was announced.
Louise Mincchin Wood with the studio
moved to Sulford joined the other main
presenters of BBC Breakfast, Bill
Turnbull, Susanna Reed and Charlie
State. Carol Kirkwood on March 26th,
2012 would remain in London presenting
with her. Sports presenters Mike Bushell
and Sally Nugent and business presenter
Steph McGovern would locate to Sulford.
The first breakfast edition from Sulford
occurred on Tuesday 10th April
2012. London-based newspapers have
reported extensive criticism of the BBC
move, but a decrease in audience has not
occurred with the retention of an
approximate average of 1.5 million
viewers. The 2012 Summer Olympics
prompted Olympic breakfast on the
morning of the opening ceremony to
temporarily broadcast from an interim
studio near the Olympic Park in
Stratford. During the games, former
presenters Shan Williams and Chris
Holland also returned to lead the
morning program in addition to Bill
Turnbull and BBC Sport presenter Hazel
Lvine. The show ended its temporary
London return with broadcasting from the
BBC News Channel studio on the morning
following the closing ceremonies before
rebroadcasting from Sulford the next
day. On March 19th, 2013, BBC Breakfast
updated its lower thirds to match the
graphics and fonts used by the rest of
BBC News since the previous day. The
clock was consequently moved to the
lower right side of the screen. On July
23rd, 2014, the show went on location
again, this time to Glasgow to showcase
highlights from the 2014 Commonwealth
Games. In the hours leading up to the
opening ceremony, Carol Kirkwood
reported from Celtic Park format.
Between 6:00 a.m. and 830m of weekdays,
the program is simol cast on the BBC
news. During the simol cast, the sports
newses at 6.10m, 10 m, 6.35 m, 7.35m,
and 8.35 m. In addition, live sports
bulletins are broadcast from sporting
locations such as Royal Ascot and
Wimbledon with the presenter
interviewing key sporting figures.
Business updates are presented at
6.10m when the main business stories
from the newspapers are also discussed
and at
750mm either from the studio or out on
location. The United Kingdom weather
forecasting broadcast is at 15 minutes
and 45 minutes past the hour throughout
the program either from the BBC weather
center in broadcasting house or out on
location. Short regional news, travel
and weather programs are just before the
hour and the half hour throughout the
program. Once the BBC news channel
breaks away for its own programming at
8.30, a brief check of the headlines and
sports are done, then the show gradually
shifts to reporting lifestyle and
entertainmentoriented stories. The show
occasionally ends with a musical
performance from one of the guests. The
show is abbreviated during bank holidays
to just 3 hours, but still features
regional news updates and is completely
simol cast on the BBC news channel.
During weekends, there are no updates
from regional news bureaus. The first
and or second hour of the weekend
edition may occasionally feature
abbreviated versions of the BBC's other
programs such as click reporters and the
film review. The show is also simol cast
on BBC 1 and the BBC News channel, but
BBC 1 occasionally breaks away at 7.30
on Sundays to bring match of the day.
The third and fourth hour are completely
live and occasionally the last segment
on Saturdays may feature cooking.
Interactive breakfast encourages viewer
response and interaction via email,
Facebook, and Twitter. Video reports and
interviews from the program are made
available on the breakfast Facebook page
after transmission.

significance of the story 11th
2001 Jeremy Bowen presented live near
ground zero in New York City following
the days of the aftermath of the tragic
events November 2004 Four. Dermit
Managen presented from Washington DC.
For the 2004 US election, July 7th,
2005, Bill Turnbull presented live from
King's Cross in the aftermath of the 7th
July 2005 London
bombings.
2005, Shan Williams reported live from
the scene of the Indian earthquake. June
2006, Dermit Managen presented from the
election campaign from Bristol. November
2008, Bill Turnbull reported live from
Washington DC. For the US presidential
elections on June 3rd, 2010, Turnbull
presented live from the town of White
Haven following the Cumbria shootings
the previous day. September 2009, Kate
Silverton presented from Lashkagar,
Afghanistan.
September
2009, Bill Turnbull presented live from
Brighton for the Liberal Democrats
Conference. September
2009, Shan Williams presented from the
Labor and Conservative Party
conferences. March 2010, Susanna Reed
presented from the Academy Awards
Ceremony. April 6th, 2010, Shan Williams
presented from Westminster in the run-up
to the announcement of the 2010 general
election. April May 2010, Bill Turnbull
presented and reported from various
locations on party campaign trail
throughout the country. April 30th,
2010, Charlie State presented the
program from the University of
Birmingham following the final leaders
debate of the election campaign. May
12th,
2010, Shan Williams presented the
program from College Green, Westminster,
the day after David Cameron became prime
minister. May 12th, 2010, Bill Turnbull
presented from outside 10 Downing
Street. July 27th, 2010, Bill Turnbull
presented on the progress of the Olympic
Park in Stratford, East London, starting
2 years before the opening ceremony of
the 2012 Summer Olympics. Chris Holland
presented the sports news from the same
location.
September 2010, Bill Turnbull presented
from their party conference in Liverpool
and the Labour conference in Manchester.
October 2010, Shan Williams presented
from the Tory conference in Birmingham.
October 2010, Shan Williams presented
from College Green, Westminster in
anticipation of the unveiling of
Chancellor George Osborne spending
review. October 2010, Shan Williams
presented the unveiling of Chancellor
George Osborne spending review. On April
29th, 2011, a special split edition of
the program with Shan presenting from
Westminster Abby and Bill live from
Buckingham Palace for the buildup of the
royal wedding. July 26th,
2012, Charlie State and Louise Mincchin
presented the show live from the BBC
News studio in Olympic Park in London
for the Olympic Games. Weather and
sports news were also originated from
the same location. April 17th,
2013. Charlie State presented the show
from St. Paul's Cathedral, London for a
special split edition in the buildup of
the funeral of Baroness Lady Thatcher.
27th and 28th June
2014. Bill Turnbull presented from Camp
Bastion to celebrate Armed Forces Day
August 4th 2014.
Charlie stayed presented from Glasgow
Cathedral in the leadup to ceremonies
marking 100 years since World War I
broke out. March 13th,
2015. Bill Turnbull presented from St.
Paul's Cathedral, London in the leadup
to a special service of remembrance to
mark the end of operations in
Afghanistan. Video podcast. In September
2006, Breakfast launched its own video
podcast called The Breakfast Takeaway.
BBC News had already launched three
other services. Niss night, the 10:00
news, and Story Fix. The Breakfast
Takeaway was available Monday to Friday
in MP4 format where it could be
downloaded to and viewed from a home or
office computer. The video podcasts were
a one-year trial, and from July 2007,
they were discontinued. The BBC then
reviewed the trial, but the podcast has
not been continued. specials. In 2003,
the breakfast production team was
commissioned by BBC 1 to make a
week-long series called The Day Team
from Chadzsworth, presented by Nikki
Chapman and presenter of the BBC's
Country File program, John Craraven. It
took a behindthescenes look at the
stately home Chadzsworth House and was
broadcast separately on BBC 1 at 10:30
in the morning. A number of other guests
or celebrity presenters have been used
on breakfast to present themed days or
weeks. Even though some have never been
mainstream news reporters or presenters,
many of these have seen the program
extended to 0930. Alistister Appleton,
Tate Modern, 2004, Bath, Somerset 2003.
Chris Beard Shaw, Chelsea Flower Show
2006. Jenny Bond, Buckingham Palace
2004. Nikki Chapman, Children in Need,
November 2005, London Fashion Week 2004,
Chelsea Flower Show 2006, Philip of
Forester, Older Hey Children's Hospital
2002, Andy Peters, Neighbors Set 2005,
East Enders Albert Square Outside
Broadcast 2006, Gabby Roslin, Wimbledon
Tennis Championships Outside Broadcast
2002, Tim Wanicott, Christy's Auction
Room 2004,
awards. In March 2006, Breakfast won the
TRIC Award for best daytime television
program for the third year in a row. The
show was nominated for a national
television award in the topical magazine
program category in 2011, but lost out
to ITV's This Morning. See also
Breakfast Television Today.
